title: Mitochondrial Dysfunction and Diseases
content: An expert in mitochondrial biology shares knowledge on the mitochondrion organelle: its history, function, genome architecture, and research of rare mitochondrial dysfunction. The focus is on finding clinical treatments for the 300-some identified rare mitochondrial disorders. This work has potential implications for longevity and chronic disease. The latest research could give insight into conditions related to aging, including but not limited to Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes, cancer, and much more.

title: Potential Therapies for Mitochondrial Diseases
content: Some of the most exciting potential therapies for mitochondrial diseases include hypoxia (oxygen deprivation), how exercise affects the mitochondria, the use of hyperbaric chambers for cancer therapy, and the mechanisms by which metformin might confer longevity benefits in a non-diabetic individual.

title: Mitochondrial Genome and Diseases
content: The mitochondrial genome: Lineage, endosymbiosis, and reductive evolution. How many diseases can be attributed to mitochondrial mutations? Nuclear DNA and mtDNA: Roles, interaction, communication, and biogenesis. Which cells have the most mitochondrial DNA? And how often does mitochondria turn-over in a cell? Does ALL of your mitochondrial DNA come from your mother?

title: Mitochondria and Aging
content: NAD and NADH: Role in the mitochondria, decline of NAD levels with age, and what it means to age at a mitochondrial level. Could muscle cell inflammation (a signature of aging) be caused by mtDNA damage being confused as foreign bacteria? Is there an optimal exercise strategy to slow the aging process? What autophagy means in the context of mitochondria.

title: Metformin and Longevity
content: Metformin’s impact on exercise and lactate levels. How might metformin confer longevity benefits?

title: Hypoxia and Mitochondrial Disease
content: Hypoxia as a potential therapeutic option for mitochondrial disease.

title: Cancer and Mitochondria
content: Cancer prevention and treatment: hyperbaric oxygen chambers, targeting single carbon metabolism of the mitochondria, and more.

title: Mitochondrial Dysfunction and Parkinson’s Disease
content: Chronic diseases have altered mitochondria: Evidence for mitochondrial dysfunction causing Parkinson’s Disease.

title: Mitochondrial Proteins as Therapies
content: The possibility of targeting mitochondrial proteins as therapies.

title: Genetically Engineering Mitochondria
content: Is it theoretically possible to genetically engineer a better functioning mitochondria?

title: Insights on Alzheimer’s disease, cancer, exercise, nutrition, and fasting
content: Latest insights on Alzheimer’s disease, cancer, exercise, nutrition, and fasting.

title: Impact of stress on physical and emotional health
content: The impact of stress on our physical and emotional health.

title: Optimizing brain health
content: Optimizing brain health: Alzheimer's disease risk factors, APOE, prevention strategies, and more.

title: Training principles for longevity
content: Training principles for longevity.

title: Preventing cardiovascular disease
content: Preventing cardiovascular disease: the latest in diagnostic imaging, blood pressure, metabolic health, and more.

title: Pros and cons of GLP-1 weight loss drugs and metformin as a geroprotective agent
content: Pros and cons of GLP-1 weight loss drugs and metformin as a geroprotective agent.

title: Overcoming trauma, finding inner peace, and living a meaningful and fulfilling life
content: Overcoming trauma, finding inner peace, and living a meaningful and fulfilling life.

title: The history of the cell, cell therapy, gene therapy
content: The history of the cell, cell therapy, gene therapy, and more.

title: Mitochondrial biology and its implications in longevity and chronic disease
content: In this episode, an expert in mitochondrial biology shares his breadth of knowledge on the mitochondrion organelle: its history, function, genome architecture, and his research of rare mitochondrial dysfunction. The research could give insight into conditions related to aging, including but not limited to Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease, insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes, cancer, and much more. We also explore some of the most exciting potential therapies for mitochondrial diseases such as hypoxia (oxygen deprivation), how exercise affects the mitochondria, the use of hyperbaric chambers for cancer therapy, and the mechanisms by which Metformin might confer longevity benefits in a non-diabetic individual.

title: Medical School and Research
content: The advice that I’d gotten when I was in college was that the reason to go to medical school, if you’re interested in research, is that it’s one of the best curricula for understanding physiology, how all of the parts come together and operate, and [for] trying to understand how an entire living system operates. If you don’t go through all of medical school, if you don’t learn anatomy, if you don’t learn histology, if you don’t learn cardiovascular physiology, it’s a bit tough. In college and undecided about medical school, lean towards a PhD. Going to medical school is one of the best ways to understand human physiology. In medical school and presumably at least somewhat interested in medicine still, do an internal medicine residency. At least do an internship in order to have a license and can prescribe medicine.

title: Mitochondrial Disorders and Research
content: He leads a research group that focuses on mitochondria and mitochondrial disorders. The long term goal is for his research to impact patients: rather than care for them directly he works to develop new diagnostics and drugs, which will be used in front-line patient treatment. A lecture on myopathies (muscular diseases) in a medical school histology and pathology class brought to his attention that there is a rare form of myopathies that are due to mutations in the mitochondrial DNA.

title: Mitochondrial Genome and Evolution
content: The bacteria organism had a full electron transport chain and was likely capable of doing aerobic metabolism using oxygen as a terminal electron acceptor. The current theory of origin is a process known as endosymbiosis: a bacteria organism resembling a modern gram-negative rods (a bacteria shaped like a rod that is gram-negatively stained for identification) that merged with a modern-day archaea species. The hypothesis is that the bacteria merged with modern-day archaea, giving rise to eukaryotes with a nuclei (three domains of life: Archaea, Bacteria, Eukaryote), around 1.5 billion years ago.

title: Mitochondrial DNA and Diseases
content: The mitochondrial genome encodes two ribosomal RNAs, 22 tRNAs and then 13 proteins. There are about 250 different syndromes (particular mutation associated with a clinical phenotype) of the mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA). There is not a solid understanding of whether mtDNA mutations have a higher or lower frequency on a probability basis (with 16,000 base pairs) compared to the nuclear genome. Mitochondrial disease is largely attributed to maternal inheritance.

title: Mitochondrial Biogenesis
content: About 1,100 proteins that are made by the nuclear genome find their way into the mitochondrion. Those 1,100 proteins have to work with the 13 mtDNA proteins within the organelle. Some mechanisms are known and many are not. For example, in response to exercise there is a transcriptional program response within the organelle, replication factors turn on in the organelle that essentially says: “make more of the nuclear DNA components, mitochondrial DNA components and mitochondrial DNA-encoded proteins”. The transcription program increases mitochondrial density in a given cell.

title: Mitochondrial DNA Inheritance
content: The textbook teaching is that mtDNA is transmitted exclusively via maternal lineage. Mechanistically, mtDNA is passed on from mom to child for two primary reasons: maternal mtDNA grossly outnumbers paternal mtDNA due to sexual dimorphism: by sheer dilution (because the egg is so huge – having millions of copies of mtDNA compared to sperm mtDNA that has few hundred copies), it’s difficult for the dad’s mtDNA to get transmitted. Paternal mtDNA are actively destroyed after fertilization.

title: Mitochondria and Energy Transformation
content: The mitochondria is the key place where energy transformations take place. A cell takes in glucose, free fatty acid, substrate for energy and in 10 steps glucose gets turned into pyruvate. Once glucose gets turned into pyruvate, there are two scenarios dependent on oxygen availability and ATP demand: if oxygen is scarce relative to ATP demand, the “inefficient” route is that pyruvate gets turned into lactate. With low ATP demand and sufficient oxygen, pyruvate converts into Acetyl-CoA, a substrate for the electron transport chain.

title: Electron Transport Chain and Energy Transformation
content: The electron transport chain is present in multiple copies in the inner mitochondrial membrane of eukaryotes and it is the last component of cellular aerobic respiration. The electron transport chain is a series of electron transporters embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane that shuttles electrons from NADH and FADH2 to molecular oxygen, using a proton pump to create a proton gradient across a membrane. In the process, protons are pumped from the mitochondrial matrix to the intermembrane space, and oxygen is reduced to form water. The mitochondria takes fats, carbohydrates and proteins and breaks down the energy forms, harnessing the electrons. The NADH/NAD ratio is an electron carrier that can power certain types of enzymes. Alternatively, the NADH/NAD ratio can also be converted to a gradient, or voltage, across the inner mitochondrial membrane that can drive transport.

title: Role of NAD and NADH in Mitochondria
content: The classical teaching is that NAD is the oxidized form (without two electrons) electron carrier. When NAD has two electrons it will be in NADH form – holding energy that can catalyze reactions. Electrons are transferred from NADH to the electron transport chain that “conducts” the electron until they hit oxygen and make water. During that process, protons are pumped across the inner mitochondrial membrane generating about 150 MV that can be used to do work – including catalyzing conversion of ADP to ATP (oxidative phosphorylation). In addition to the role of NAD as an electron carrier, the NAD molecule can also be used as a substrate for other reactions.

title: Aging at a Mitochondrial Level
content: NAD levels decline with age and elicits some key questions: Is that due to greater demand for it? Is that due to reduction in (NAD) production? And the clinical question is if there is any benefit to replacing it? Comparing a muscle biopsy of individuals of various ages, there will be a gradual decline as a function of age in: NAD content, quantity of mitochondria, the VO2 max of skeletal muscle. The big question in the field is: does “old and sick” tissue mean “sick” mitochondria, or will targeting the mitochondria actually somehow alleviate age-associated decline in tissue function?

title: Mitochondrial Diseases
content: Mitochondrial diseases are typically single gene disorders of a mitochondrion that is defective at birth due to: Recessive mutations in the nuclear genome, Mutations in the mitochondrial genome. There are about 300 mitogenic disorders of the mitochondria. The phenotypic spectrum of these mutations follow a bimodal distribution. Patients need new treatments and therapies but there are also mutations, of which the study will inform more common forms of aging (the link between mitochondrial decline and aging).

title: Mitochondria and Oxygen
content: When mitochondria and oxygen are discussed, ROS signaling commonly comes to mind. Mitochondria are an important source of ROS – an essential signaling molecule. In addition to producing ATP, the mitochondria also consume oxygen. In fact, most of the oxygen in a cell is consumed by the mitochondria. When a patient has a birth defect of the mitochondria, in addition to not being able to produce sufficient ATP, they also have excess oxygen. Oxygen delivery to the cell is typically not a problem but the oxygen utilization is poor.

title: Mitochondrial Function and Type 2 Diabetes
content: In early states of insulin resistance the muscle becomes inefficient at oxidative phosphorylation (marked by high levels of resting lactate). A series of papers in early 2000s demonstrated that skeletal muscles from individuals with prediabetes, as well as biopsies of healthy individuals with a family history of diabetes, have a reduced number of mitochondria. 1000 genes required for mitochondria are suppressed as an entire pathway (not any one gene). Vo2 max for these individuals is also low. It is still not clear if mitochondrial dysfunction is causal for diabetes or if it is an early, secondary symptom that precedes mitochondria gene expression.

title: Mitochondrial Disease and Aging
content: Rare genetic disorders reveal pathology pathogenesis of the organelle that can potentially be applied to common aging phenomena. Implications of understanding mitochondrial disease pathway are significant both for chronic and risk reduction of chronic disease. The mitochondrion is a highly reactive organelle: if other processes in the cell fail then the mitochondrion is also at risk for failing. The big question in the field of rare mitogenetic disorders: which forms of the pathogenesis bears any relevance to the common aging process?

title: Muscle Cell Inflammation and Aging
content: Another signature of time is inflammation within muscle cells. Muscles become more inflamed as they age. What is drawing inflammatory cells into muscle as we age?

title: Mitochondria and Immune Response
content: A recent paper used STING pathway to block the ability of a cell to sense breakdown in nucleic acid. The hypothesis is that mtDNA is bacterial in origin and a loose fragment of bacterial DNA in a cell would produce an immunogenic reaction. With increased mitochondrial damage in a cell results in elevated exposure of the mtDNA, eliciting an immunogenic response. To test the hypothesis, STING pathway was utilized – blocking the ability of a cell to sense general nucleic acid. Another study finding supported inflammation in response to mtDNA and formulated peptides. Fractionation identified that sterile crush injury inflammation was in response to mitochondrial derived molecules.

title: Exercise and Mitochondrial Health
content: Exercise is one of the best ways to turn over bad mitochondria and induce mitochondrial biogenesis. But exercise does a lot of things, so positive mitochondrial impact does not adequately answer the aging-mitochondrial health relationship. Is there an optimal exercise strategy for mitochondrial health? At the center of the optimal exercise question is understanding the role of exercise in mitochondrial health. Three types of (loose) exercise buckets being strength training, aerobic training requiring maximum mitochondrial output with minimal generation of lactate, anaerobic training that demands ATP and favors the lactate production pathway.

title: Metformin’s Impact on Exercise and Lactate Levels
content: As discussed with Nir Barzilai, individuals with diabetes and also those who are insulin resistant are benefited by metformin. Peter self-experiments to observe the effects of metformin on exercise. His lactate performance curve (LPC) comparison reveals higher lactate levels when on metformin. His resting lactate level on Metformin also increased. Hypothesis for increased lactate is that Metformin inhibits complex one, the body may preferentially opt against shuttling pyruvate into the mitochondria, disproportionately keeping pyruvate outside of the organelle and turning it into lactate.

title: Hypoxia as a Potential Therapeutic Option for Mitochondrial Disease
content: There have been observations where too much oxygen can be damaging. In some rare mitochondrial disorders studied, ATP levels are defended by glycolysis (i.e., not a disorder of energy deficiency), there are high levels of unused oxygen observed. Vamsi’s lab now investigates ways to limit or reduce the delivery of oxygen. Using hypoxia chambers in mouse model studies in which air is diluted with nitrogen (21% oxygen reduced to 11%). In some of the models with mitochondrial disease there has been a measured benefit.

title: Cancer Prevention and Treatment
content: There is a subset of tumors – where there may be mitochondrial mutations to begin with – for which Vamsi’s lab is exploring hyperoxic exposure. Hyperbaric oxygen has been proposed as a cancer therapy in the past. It may be that with precise targeting, (based on mitochondria markers) hyperbaric oxygen can be effectively used for certain cancer treatments. Other learnings that could be applied to cancer prevention or treatment include a series of projects in Vamsi’s lab took data sets from cancers to see which metabolic pathways were consistently altered.

title: Chronic Diseases and Mitochondrial Dysfunction
content: Not clear if dysfunctional mitochondria is the cause or part of the disease effect. Systems biology and insights taken from rare disease research may inform a subset of chronic disease understanding. The causal hypothesis for Parkinson’s Disease is particularly compelling. The pathology of rare monogenic mitochondrial disease resembles molecular features of mitochondrial dysfunction seen in Parkinson’s Disease. In some Parkinson’s Disease cases, the root cause is mitochondrial toxicity that results in dopamine loss (via herbicide or insecticide exposure, which are toxic to Complex I).

title: Targeting Mitochondrial Proteins as Therapies
content: In the laboratory, mitochondrial disease can be alleviated in a preclinical way using hypoxia. Another preclinical approach uses protein prosthesis. Proteins from other organisms are transplanted into human cells (ex-vivo) with mitochondrial disease and effectively rescue the cells. As a result of reductive evolution, certain organisms lost parts of their ETC and others, their entire ETC. One way organisms who have lost their entire ETC may be able to survive is because they gained a new protein in replacement. These isolated proteins placed in a human cell can poison the mitochondria in five different ways but the cell will reproduce.

title: Natural Products and Health
content: In biology, it is easy to break a system by one thing but it is hard to enhance it with one thing. Drugs like statins, metformin, rapamycin all act on multiple “switches” at the same time that are net beneficial. It is no coincidence that most effective, potent clinical agents, that involve such “multi-pronged” inputs within a system, come from naturally occurring substances. Natural products are chemistries that have evolved over hundreds of millions of years to target physiological systems.

title: Oxygen Depletion and Health
content: One possible experiment would be motivated by his lab’s recent work on oxygen and mitochondrial dysfunction. In preclinical models, oxygen depleted air seems to be beneficial. In normal aging, when there is a subtle decline in mitochondrial activity, is there excess oxygen and would breathing thinner air be beneficial?

title: Experimental Design for Oxygen Depletion Study
content: Crossover study with two treatment groups at different elevation. Large participant cohort. Treatment length in the order of months to years. Compare biomarkers of aging and age associated disorders. To test the idea that thin air might be beneficial for chronic disease.

title: Health Outcomes at Different Altitudes
content: This type of natural experiment has actually been reported in one paper from the early 1970s, published by the Indian army. The study reported on health outcomes of more than 100,000 troops deployed to the Indo-China border. One group was at extremely high altitude and another group was not for a number of years. Although other parameters – such as food, temperature, activity – were not controlled for, the altitudes and therefore oxygen saturation between the two locations were different.

title: Health Consequences at Different Altitudes
content: Death from infection were much higher at altitude. Chronic diseases were reduced during the time living at altitude.
